unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Language Spoken at Home: Finding a Probability
question_text:
According to U.S. Census reports (2009-2013), $20.7\%$ of individuals age $5$ and over reported that they “sometimes or always spoke a language other than English at home”. Suppose that this percentage has not changed.
If six individuals over the age $5$ are selected at random, what is the probability that at least one would report that they sometimes or always speak a language other than English at home?
solution:
Let $X$ the number of people in the randomly selected sample of $6$ who would say that they sometimes or always speak a language other than English at home. We want to find $p(X\ge1)$. There are two ways to approach this problem.

The first approach uses the addition rule. That is:

$$p(X\ge1) = p(X=1) + p(X=2) + p(X=3) + p(X=4) + p(X=5) + p(X=6)$$

While this would work, it is rather tedious and involves many binomial probability calculations.

The second approach uses the complement principle. That is:

$$p(X\ge1) = 1 - p(X<1)$$

$$p(\text{at least one speaks other language}) = 1 - p(\text{none speak other language})$$

This method is much easier and quicker.

Since, $p(\text{speak other language}) = 0.207$, we know:

$$p(\text{doesn't speak other language})=1 – 0.207 = 0.793$$

Then:

$$p(\text{none speak other language})=(0.793)(0.793)(0.793)(0.793)(0.793)(0.793) = 0.2487$$

Finally:

$$p(X\ge1)=1 – 0.2487 = 0.7513$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. It represents the probability that the first person in the sample would say that they speak a language other than English and the next $5$ would say they do not. This answer can be arrived at using the following calculation: $(0.207)(0.793^5)$

Choice 'B' is incorrect. In this calculation, the probability that all $6$ individuals would say that they do NOT speak a language other than English was calculated, but was not subtracted from $1$.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. It represents the probability that exactly $1$ of the $6$ individuals surveyed would say that they speak a language other than English. This answer is arrived at using the following calculation: $5(0.207)(0.793^5)$

Choice 'D' is incorrect. It is the complement of answer Choice 'C'.
